results.title: [Remix: Sunnies]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Worn at the beach or on a bush walk, or simply as a style statement, this playful short film is a tribute to the fashion accessory, and sun-smart, sun glasses. Set to a boss nova soundtrack, this short work is a tribute to ‘shades’, showing people wearing sun glasses cut from home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection. Featured are some of fashion’s best styles of eye wear from the 1940s to the 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Elenor Peach; Barry Parsons; The Gadsden Family and Neville Daley.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Vegetable Growing at Home
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film is a government-produced educational film designed to encourage viewers to grow their own vegetables at home during the Second World War. Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, the film features a suburban couple who receive a brochure in the mail called ‘Wartime Vegetable Growing at Home’. The educational intent of the film is interspersed with comic scenes predicated on the (now outdated) gender roles of the time as the domestic housewife, Mary, sabotages her husband’s plans to play golf and convinces him to start a vegetable garden. With the assistance of the girl next door, a student at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the hapless husband begins transforming his patch of grass and stops sulking. Moving to an instructional section filmed at the Burnley School of Horticulture, the film’s narrator explains how to dig a patch, turn over and rake the soil, and plant seeds, with the process performed by another expert female gardener (despite clearly being a skilled professional, the narrator mocks her for being a woman). The gardener then demonstrates how to thin out young plants, cultivate the soil and deal with pests, with occasional interludes back to the comic scenes of the domestic couple. Finally, the film shows the rewards of growing your own vegetables, with a bountiful harvest from the garden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Grampians wonderland
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description:
The Grampians mountain ranges rising from the plains of western Victoria were discovered by Major Mitchell and continue to delight tourists. This program shows the exquisite wildflowers, the animal life, the rugged mountain scenery and the foaming waterfalls which make the Grampians so beautiful and so popular. Winner of an AFI Award: 1959.

The convertable car used in this film is a Triumph TR3A.

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: Melons for Jam
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an instructional film on fruit preserving. Expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates the process for making melon jam in a domestic kitchen. This film is a fascinating insight into household kitchens and cooking in the 1950s, particularly before widespread international food import enabled greater fruit produce availability all year.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.description: This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an instructional film on fruit preserving. Expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates the process for making melon jam in a domestic kitchen. This film is a fascinating insight into household kitchens and cooking in the 1950s, particularly before widespread international food import enabled greater fruit produce availability all year.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.
results.description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.
description_for_label:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.

results.title: Carmel: storyteller
results.brief_description: Carmel is a retired school teacher, wife, mother and grandmother. Her family’ s life dramatically changed when she was diagnosed with early onset memory loss. With her husband, she tells their story and looks positively in the face of an unknown future. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington, also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 24:

Reel 24 contains footage of the royal visit to Flemington (also seen in Reels 1, 9, and 10 of this Collection). It opens with footage of the Queen and Duke arriving, followed by aerial shots of the horses, jockeys and course. 00:03:25:00 the Queen presenting the winners’ trophy begins. 00:05:50:00 footage of horses racing. 00:07:40:00 to 00:08:33:00 the footage action is in reverse (including Queen and official party, horses and jockeys in mounting yard and racing, and crowd scenes.)
